drop off.translation[0].definitions[0].e: She kept dropping off at her desk.
I must have dropped off to sleep.
drop off.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to take someone or something to a place by car and leave them there on your way to another place
drop off.translation[0].definitions[1].e: Iâ€™ll drop you off on my way home.
drop off.translation[0].definitions[2].d: to fall to a lower level or amount
drop off.translation[0].definitions[2].e: The number of graduates going into teaching has dropped off sharply.
drop off.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to become lower in level or amount
drop off.translation[1].definitions[0].e: Sales have dropped off in recent months.
With the strong pound, tourism has dropped off.
drop off.translation[2].definitions[0].d: if there is a drop-off in the amount, level, or number of something, it goes down or becomes less
drop off.translation[2].definitions[0].e: There has been a drop-off in tourism this year.
drop off.translation[2].definitions[1].d: a delivery, or the place where something is delivered to
drop off.translation[2].definitions[1].e: A truckload carrier takes a full cargo from one point to another, without any intervening pickups or drop-offs.
